item.title: Reflecting getPlayerX and getPlayerY problem
item.dc:creator: @the_bank the bank
item.description:
@the_bank wrote:

[quote=“Cheese_Police, post:20, topic:263735”][quote author=the bank link=topic=348302.msg2680037#msg2680037 date=1235309909]

Then everyone else is gonna follow along in da bad naming. I mean… StringWrapper.
[/quote]StringWrapper makes more sense then RSString because it is also used in funorb, and JagString sounds like shit. There is already a String class so people that call it “string” because the believe that jagex follows a C naming-style, also doesn’t look good.

The class people call “StringWrapper” is infact a “wrapper”, which is immediately noticeable after looking at the functions in the class, however it is not for a String, it is for a byte[].

One could argue that it should be called ByteArrayWrapper.

“StringWrapper” is Jagex’s implementation of an ASCII string, not a wrapper for one. It is independent of java.lang.String (although there is probably a conversion method). Also, in the unobfuscated login applet that was released, the class was infact named JagString (or some variant in the capitalization).[/quote]Really? I was unaware of that, thank you.

+1

EDIT:

Might you have a link to the login applet?

Read full topic

@Cheese_Police wrote:

[quote=“the bank, post:19, topic:263735”][quote author=marluxia link=topic=348302.msg2679863#msg2679863 date=1235299081]
Then everyone else is gonna follow along in da bad naming. I mean… StringWrapper.
[/quote]StringWrapper makes more sense then RSString because it is also used in funorb, and JagString sounds like shit. There is already a String class so people that call it “string” because the believe that jagex follows a C naming-style, also doesn’t look good.

The class people call “StringWrapper” is infact a “wrapper”, which is immediately noticeable after looking at the functions in the class, however it is not for a String, it is for a byte[].

One could argue that it should be called ByteArrayWrapper.[/quote]

“StringWrapper” is Jagex’s implementation of an ASCII string, not a wrapper for one. It is independent of java.lang.String (although there is probably a conversion method). Also, in the unobfuscated login applet that was released, the class was infact named JagString (or some variant in the capitalization).

item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

not really, the array does contain the locations of the player the index 0 contains the current and the other 4 indexes contain past locations,

[code] - cc.getLocationX() returns cc.V

  • cc.getLocationY() returns cc.kb[/code]

item.title: Reflecting getPlayerX and getPlayerY problem
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

[quote=“DarkXeD, post:6, topic:263735”]i am trying nueb35

But some functions are just not worth of it to recode… since to much work on them

however new problem…

String PlayerClass = "cg";
String PlayerField = "P";
String CharX = "V";
String CharY = "kb"; 

Field getCharX;
Field getCharY;
Field player;
Class character;

public Field getField(String clazz, String field) {
	try {
		Class clazzObj = (Class) loadClass.invoke(rsLoader, clazz, false);
		Field fieldObj = clazzObj.getDeclaredField(field);
		fieldObj.setAccessible(true);
		return fieldObj;
	} catch (Exception e) {
		System.out.println("Error - Class: " + clazz + "; Field: " + field);
		e.printStackTrace();
		return null;
       	}
}

	
public Client() {
	player = getField(PlayerClass, PlayerField);
	character = player.getType().getSuperclass();
	getCharX = character.getDeclaredField(CharX);
	getCharY = character.getDeclaredField(CharY);

	getCharX.setAccessible(true);
	getCharY.setAccessible(true);

	while (true) {
		System.out.println("Position: " + getCharX.getInt(player.get(null)) + ":" + getCharY.getInt(player.get(null)));	
	}
}

Errors… idk why…

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Attempt to get [I field "cc.V" with illegal data type conversion to int
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.newGetIllegalArgumentException(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.newGetIntIllegalArgumentException(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeObjectFieldAccessorImpl.getInt(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.reflect.Field.getInt(Unknown Source)
        at com.darkxed.bot.Client.<init>(Client.java:130)
        at com.darkxed.Main.main(Main.java:7)

Is this an error of the updaters? or what did i do wrong?[/quote]

the field is an int array, and you are trying to get it as an int (dont use Field.getInt(obj), use Field.get(obj), then cast)

Read full topic

System.out.println("Position: " + ((int[])getCharX.get(playerInstance))[0] + ":" + ((int[])getCharY.get(playerInstance))[0]);

you want to get the value of “charX/Y” from the instance of player (player extends character).

item.title: Reflecting getPlayerX and getPlayerY problem
item.dc:creator: @DarkXeD DarkXeD
item.description:
@DarkXeD wrote:

i am trying nueb35

But some functions are just not worth of it to recode… since to much work on them

however new problem…

String PlayerClass = "cg";
String PlayerField = "P";
String CharX = "V";
String CharY = "kb"; 

Field getCharX;
Field getCharY;
Field player;
Class character;

public Field getField(String clazz, String field) {
	try {
		Class clazzObj = (Class) loadClass.invoke(rsLoader, clazz, false);
		Field fieldObj = clazzObj.getDeclaredField(field);
		fieldObj.setAccessible(true);
		return fieldObj;
	} catch (Exception e) {
		System.out.println("Error - Class: " + clazz + "; Field: " + field);
		e.printStackTrace();
		return null;
       	}
}

	
public Client() {
	player = getField(PlayerClass, PlayerField);
	character = player.getType().getSuperclass();
	getCharX = character.getDeclaredField(CharX);
	getCharY = character.getDeclaredField(CharY);

	getCharX.setAccessible(true);
	getCharY.setAccessible(true);

	while (true) {
		System.out.println("Position: " + getCharX.getInt(player.get(null)) + ":" + getCharY.getInt(player.get(null)));	
	}
}

Errors… idk why…

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Attempt to get [I field "cc.V" with illegal data type conversion to int
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.newGetIllegalArgumentException(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeFieldAccessorImpl.newGetIntIllegalArgumentException(Unknown Source)
        at sun.reflect.UnsafeObjectFieldAccessorImpl.getInt(Unknown Source)
        at java.lang.reflect.Field.getInt(Unknown Source)
        at com.darkxed.bot.Client.<init>(Client.java:130)
        at com.darkxed.Main.main(Main.java:7)

Is this an error of the updaters? or what did i do wrong?

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting getPlayerX and getPlayerY problem
item.dc:creator: @nueb35 Nueb35
item.description:
@nueb35 wrote:

the fields for playerX playerY as you call then are actually in the Character class, so they should be called characterX and characterY, he first gets a Field whose type is Player, then he gets the superclass which is Character form that character class he gets the fields x and y which are stored in getCharX and getCharY

form that he can get the values of these fields by doing getCharX/Y.get(characterInstance);

Read full topic

item.title: Reflecting getPlayerX and getPlayerY problem
item.dc:creator: @DarkXeD DarkXeD
item.description:
@DarkXeD wrote:

Hi i am trying to learn to do some reflection…
I am able to get CameraX, Y and Z and the Mouse Position so far…
Now i wanted to try the player position however i failed…
so i looked around and i found the unfinished reflection bot with this in it…

            player = getField(Player, player2);
            character = player.getType().getSuperclass();
            getCharX = character.getDeclaredField(PlayerX);
            getCharY = character.getDeclaredField(PlayerY);

why first player then character en then the X and Y? isn’t there a quicker method?
If not why does it need to do this?
and what is Player and Player2?

Read full topic
